Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone buzzing in my hand. My mom’s voice still echoed in my mind—she had just confided in me about her fears of growing old alone, her words trembling with vulnerability. She needed me, wanted me to sit with her, listen, maybe just hold her hand for a while. But my phone screen lit up with a message from my girlfriend: “Can’t wait to see you tonight. Only one more weekend before I leave.” I’d promised her this time, just us, no distractions. She was leaving for months, and we’d both been counting down to this last weekend together. My heart twisted, torn between the urge to comfort my mom and the promise I’d made to my girlfriend. I could feel the weight of both their expectations pressing down on me, each pulling me in a different direction. I stared at the wall, paralyzed, wishing I could be in two places at once.
